dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...I lived in a little bungalow on Napa Street. The place was OK, I guess; it had an electric ice box, gas hearth, and a garbage grinder build into the sink. You might say I had it made.

direction.raw_text: Ed starts to rise, but Big Dave is already looming over him. Big Dave bear-hugs him and then spins him into a wall. Ed hits the wall and bounces off, back into Big Dave. Big Dave wallops him in the stomach. Ed doubles over.

direction.raw_text: Big Dave hurls him against the desk, then slams his face against the desktop. Ed's hands scrabble at the top of the desk as Big Dave grabs him by the neck and lifts. He slams him face-first into the window between the office and the dark sales floor. Ed twists around, the back of his head now pressed against the glass. Big Dave's hands lock around his throat. Big Dave sweats and strains. A crack shoots up the pane of glass. Ed's hand sweeps up and plunges something into Big Dave's neck. Big Dave grunts and turns away, gurgling. His hands go up to his throat. Ed watches. He is holding Big Dave's cigar trimmer. Big Dave takes a couple of deliberate steps backward, his head twisted away. He falls back, tripped up by a chair, which spins him face- down onto the floor. Big Dave crawls away face-down across the floor, on his knees but with his hands still at his throat. His face and knees awkwardly support his weight as if he were pushing something across the floor with his nose. He reaches a corner but still pushes forward, wedging himself in, legs still scraping away as if to push himself through the wall. Blood is pooling out from under him. Big Dave's legs are still working. His gurgling continues. Ed watches. Big Dave's legs start to move furiously. They convulse. His whole body shakes as he goes into shock. Ed watches. Big Dave stops shaking. He remains wedged awkwardly into the corner, face-down. He is still. The room is very quiet. Ed looks down at his hands. He walks across the room, pushes the door open and walks across the darkened sales floor.

direction.raw_text: It is a long table with chairs stretching down both sides, one side for prisoners, the other for visitors. The room is empty except for a guard and an elderly woman who sits across from a younger woman at the far end of the table. The younger woman, in a prison smock, is wailing. The elderly woman is holding her hand. Ed sits across from an empty chair, clutching a flower-printed toiletries kit. There are echoing voices suggesting large spaces outside the room. He sits and waits. Approaching footsteps. The door opens. A large prison matron steps aside to let Doris enter. Doris looks lost in a prison-issue jumper that is too big for her. Her hair is uncurled and bedraggled. Not only is she not made-up, she has a couple of bruises and a cut on her lip. As Ed stands, she gives a hollow look around.

direction.raw_text: She looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shrugs.

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to the glass-paned doorway to his office, Frank trailing dejectedly behind. They enter, the door closes, and we hear their muffled voices from inside, the sense of the words lost. Ed sits and watches the two men perform their pantomime of business: Frank nervously reads documents with one hand cupped to his forehead for concentration; the banker passes successive documents across his desk with a word of explanation for each as Frank signs. Ed takes out a cigarette and lights it, watching impassively.

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh.

direction.raw_text: It is midday. We are tracking along the sidewalk toward a long cream-colored Packard parked at the curb. A couple of kids have stopped to peer into the car's windows; the car is no doubt the fanciest in town.

direction.raw_text: Ed, coming up the sidewalk, looks up at the storefront: a restaurant with a large window with a plush red drape that obscures the interior. Gilt lettering on the window spells out "DaVinci's".

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...to Freddy Riedenschneider, who got into town two days later...

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...and told me to meet him at DaVinci's for lunch.

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah--

dialogue.raw_text: Barber, right? I'm Freddy Riedenschneider. Hungry? They tell me the chow's OK here. I made some inquiries.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No thanks, I--

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I don't wanna waste your time so I'll eat while we talk. Ya mind? *You* don't mind. So while I'm in town I'll be staying at the Hotel Metropole, the Turandot Suite. Yeah, it's goofy, the suites're named after operas; room's OK though, I poked around. I'm having 'em hold it for me on account of I'll be back and forth. In addition to my retainer, you're paying hotel, living expenses, secretarial, private eye if we need to make inquiries, headshrinker should we go that way. We'll talk about appeals if, as and when. For right now, has she confessed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Of course not. She didn't do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good! That helps. Not that she didn't do it, that she didn't confess. Of course, there's ways to deal with a confession, but that's good!--one less thing to think about. Now. Interview. I'm seeing her tomorrow. You should be there. Three o'clock. One more thing: you keep your mouth shut. I get the lay of the land, I tell *you* what to say. No talking out of school. What's out of school? Everything's out of school. I do the talking; you keep your trap shut. I'm an attorney, you're a barber; you don't know anything. Understood?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good! Any questions give me a ring-- Turandot suite; if I'm out leave a message. You sure you don't want anything? No?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You're OK, pal. You're OK, she's OK. Everything's gonna be hunky-dory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And the flapjacks, honey.

direction.raw_text: We are looking at pedestrians on the sidewalk through the windshield of a moving car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Ed, driving.

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) All going about their business. It seemed like I knew a secret--a bigger one even then what had really happened to Big Dave, something none of them knew...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Like I had made it to the outside, somehow, and they were all still struggling, way down below.

direction.raw_text: Ed opens it as he finishes cinching a bathrobe. The woman waiting on the front porch is dressed in black: a black dress and a black veiled hat that is too big for her bird-like frame. Wind rustles in the trees behind her. She stares at Ed.

direction.raw_text: For the first time, we hear her speak, in a low, tremulous voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed nods. After an uncomfortable beat, through which she continues to stare:

direction.raw_text: She lays a black-gloved hand on his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She falls silent. The trees behind her rustle. She gives a wary look back. Then, confidingly, to Ed:

direction.raw_text: Ed is puzzled:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives him a searching look, hoping, it seems, that he will find this significant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed says nothing. She touches his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and heads down the walk. Her high-heeled footsteps echo on the walk, then the sidewalk, then are lost in the rustle of leaves. Ed watches her go: a small black figure, growing smaller.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ann--

dialogue.raw_text: A spacecraft. I saw the creatures. They led Big Dave onto the craft. He never told anyone what they did, outside of his report. Of course he told *me*. No one else.

dialogue.raw_text: Ann--

dialogue.raw_text: The government knows. I cannot repeat it to you. But this thing goes deep, Ed. This was not your wife. I goes deep, and involves the government. There is a great deal of fear. You know how certain circles would find it--the knowledge--a threat. They try to limit it, and--

dialogue.raw_text: Ann, will you come in, sit down, maybe have a drink?

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes knowledge is a curse, Ed. After this happened, things changed. Big Dave... he never touched me again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Tell Doris not to worry. I know it wasn't her. Perhaps this will bring it out, finally. Perhaps now it will all come out.

direction.raw_text: It is an unadorned room with a simple wooden table and chairs. One high window lets in a shaft of sunlight. Ed and Doris sit at the table; Freddy Riedenschneider stands to one side staring up at the high window, hands dug into his pockets. All three are motionless for a long beat. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts pacing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riedenschneider gives him a hard look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riedenschneider eyes him. Wheels start turning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doris eyes him. His manner does not reveal anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riedenschneider rolls his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed returns Riedenschneider's stare. Riedenschneider resumes pacing.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another nod indicates Ed:

direction.raw_text: His pacing becomes more animated.

direction.raw_text: He is heading for the door.

dialogue.raw_text: ...It stinks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't care it's true, it's not true; it stinks. You say he was being blackmailed; by who? You don't know. For having an affair; with who? You don't know. Did anyone else know about it? Probably not; you don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew about it. Big Dave told me about it, and the spot he was putting himself in by getting the money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terrific. Your husband backs you up. That's terrific.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You've gotta give me something to work with. Freddy Riedenschneider is good, but he's not a magician. He can't just wave his little wand in the air and make a plausible defense materialize. Look. Look at what the other side is gonna run at us. They got the company books, prepared by you--*cooked* by you--that's Motive. They got a murder scene *you* had access to. That's Opportunity. They got that little trimmer thing he was stabbed in the throat with--a *dame's* weapon--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was Big Dave's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --don't interrupt me--that's Means. They got a fine upstanding pillar of the business community as a victim, and then they got *you*, a disgruntled number-juggling underling who on the day in question was drunk as a skunk and whose alibi for the time in question is being passed out at home, alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: *I* was with her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Like I say, it stinks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: we forget the blackmail. *You* killed him. How come?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He and Doris... were having an affair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: how did you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... just knew. A husband knows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will anyone else say they knew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. I don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you get into the store?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I took Doris's keys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will anyone say they saw you there? On your way there? In there? On your was back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will anyone corroborate and goddamn part of your story at all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Come on, people. You can't help each other like that. Let's be realistic now. Let's look at our options. Well, frankly, I don't *see* any options.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I cannot present Story A.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I cannot present Story B. I could plead you for a nutcase but you look too composed. I could offer a guilty plea and in return they don't give you the juice, but I don't think you want to spend the rest of your life in Chino and I know you didn't hire Freddy Riedenschneider to hold your hand at a sentencing hearing. Hell, you could've gotten Lloyd Garroway for that. No, we're not giving up yet; you hired Freddy Riedenschneider, it means you're *not* throwing in the towel. I litigate, I don't capitulate. direction.raw_text: Ed sits on the front porch of his bungalow, smoking a cigarette in the late afternoon light. A dog barks next door; a distant screen door slams; children are playing somewhere up the street. Ed looks down at his watch. It is 5:30. Something attracts his attention: at the foot of his driveway stands a man in a cream-colored suit and hat. He is a small figure, perfectly still, staring at the gravel driveway. After a beat he lifts up a small clipboard, squints at the house, and jots something down. He finishes writing, screws the lid back onto his pen, and is sticking it into a breast pocket when he realizes he is being watched. His manner instantly warms.

dialogue.raw_text: Birdy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Birdy. The girl. No, the girl's OK. Broken clavicle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...That's the collarbone, Crane. Broken. She's OK though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So he understands? He's under arrest for murder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Big Dave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd he say? Does he understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He said OK. Is that what he said?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're under arrest for the murder of Creighton Tolliver! Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Does he understand?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The pansy. A kid diving at a waterhole outside of town had found his car...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...They'd winched it out...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We are tracking laterally across a line of faces: seated men. The men rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We arc around a judge entering the chamber through the small door behind his raised bench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The judge seats himself and we resume out lateral track on the jury, now reseating itself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In response to a prompt from the judge the district attorney rises to read the charge. His voice plays distantly, muted, the words not discernible under the continuing voice-over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riedenschneider rises into frame at the defense table. As he listens to the charge:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The drone of the D.A. has ended and Riedenschneider's echoing voice drops into the hole:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riedenschneider claps Ed reassuringly on the shoulder as he sits next to him. Ed still wears a cast on one arm and one leg.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...and found he'd been beaten, just like Big Dave said--beaten to death...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Inside the briefcase were the partnership papers I'd signed...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...showing that I'd given him ten grand. For the district attorney...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...that made it fall into place: I'd gotten Doris to steal the money, the pansy had gotten wise somehow, and I'd had to kill him to cover my tracks. I was in a spot. I called in Freddy Riedenschneider...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...and signed the house over to him. He said he didn't ordinarily work that cheap, but he figured he owed me something since the last one hadn't played out...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not guilty, your honor...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I tried to tell him the whole story, but Riedenschneider stopped me. He said the story made his head hurt, and anyway he didn't see any way of using it without putting me on the hot seat for the murder of Big Dave...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...He told me not to worry, though, said he'd think of something, Freddy Riedenschneider wouldn't let me down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We are tracking in on Ed, lying on the bunk in his cell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A reverse track shows a guard on a tilted-back straightbacked chair, outside the cell door, staring at Ed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...They put me on twenty-four-hour deathwatch...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...so that I couldn't Cheat Justice like they said my wife had done...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The district attorney is rising again, this time to address the jury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The district attorney is pointing at Ed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The district attorney seats himself. The jury's eyes turn to Freddy Riedenschneider, who studies the tabletop in front of him, either digesting the D.A.'s opening statement, or seeking inspiration for his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riedenschneider rises, paces, begins to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We pan the jury, solemnly listening to Riedenschneider.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riedenschneider is striding energetically into the foreground to point a finger directly at Ed's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tap on the shoulder turns Ed around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank socks Ed, sending him clattering to the floor. A bailiff immediately restrains him, but Frank looms over Ed, bellowing through tears:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riedenschneider interposes his body between Frank's and Ed's, loudly protesting:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed moves to get up, but Riedenschneider, with a sidelong glance and furtive gesture, motions for him to stay on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed is now standing next to a distinguished older gentleman who enters the plea in the new trial:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The judge starts droning the sentence:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...But in front of the jury they had it that Doris was a saint; the whole plan had been mine, I was a Svengali who'd forced Doris to join my criminal enterprise...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...cynically used his own wife as a cat's paw in a scheme of diabolical cunning...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) On and on it went, how I'd used Doris and then let her take the fall. That stuff smarted because some of it was close to being true...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...And then it was Freddy Riedenschneider's turn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...I gotta hand it to him, he tossed a lot of sand in their eyes. He talked about how I'd lost my place in the universe...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...a puny player on the great world's stage...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...how I was too ordinary to be the criminal mastermind the D.A. made me out to be, how there was some greater scheme at work that the state had yet to unravel, and he threw in some of the old truth stuff he hadn't had a chance to trot out for Doris...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...who among us is in a position to say...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...He told them to look at me--look at me close. That the closer they looked the less sense it would all make, that I wasn't the kind of guy to kill a guy, that I was the barber, for Christ's sake...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...I was just like them, an ordinary man, guilty of living in a world that had no place for me, guilty of wanting to be a dry cleaner, sure, but not of murder...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...He said I *was* Modern Man, and if they voted to convict me, well, they'd be practically cinching the noose around their own necks. He told them to look not at the facts but at the meaning of the facts, and then he said the facts *had* no meaning. It was a pretty good speech, and even had me going...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...until Frankie interrupted it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of man *are* you? What kind of man *are* you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Move for a mistrial, your honor! Move for a mistrial! This outrageous display cannot help but prejudice...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and inflame the passions of these twelve fine men and women...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Well, he got his mistrial, but the well had run dry. There was nothing left to mortgage; Riedenschneider went home and the court appointed Lloyd Garroway...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your honor, we plead guilty, with extenuating circumstances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...who threw me on the mercy of the court. It was my only chance, he said. I guess that meant I never had a chance...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...a menace to society... a predator on his own wife, his business associates, on an innocent young girl... social contract... line crossed... the offender forfeits the right to his own life... I hereby order that you be taken to a place of confinement...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We are tracking down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed is in the cell at the end of the hall, lying on his bunk, hands clasped behind his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) He wasn't buying any of that Modern Man stuff, or the uncertainty stuff, or any of the mercy stuff either. No, he was going by the book, and the book said I got the chair...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...so here I am. At first I didn't know how I got here. I knew step by step of course, which is what I've told you, step by step; but I couldn't see any pattern...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ed sits at the little table next to his bunk, writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Recent issues of the magazine, Gent, and its sister publication Nugget lie on the little desk. Their lurid covers depict feature stories like I WAS ABDUCTED BY ALIENS and AFTER TEN YEARS OF NORMAL LIFE, I DISCOVER I AM AN ESCAPED LUNATIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed sets aside the pen, lies down on his bunk, and closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear a pulsing treble hum. Ed opens his eyes. The door to his cell is open. He rises and goes through the door.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: AFTER TEN YEARS OF NORMAL LIFE, I DISCOVER I AM AN ESCAPED LUNATIC

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Now that I'm near the end, I'm glad that this men's magazine paid me to tell my story. Writing it has helped me sort it all out. They're paying five cents a word, so you'll pardon me if sometimes I've told you more than you wanted to know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...But now, all the disconnected things seems to hook up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...That's the funny thing about going away, knowing the date you're gonna die--and the men's magazine wanted me to tell how that felt...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ed, alone, walks down the hallway. The pulsing treble hum is louder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Well, it's like pulling away from the maze. While you're in the maze you go through willy-nilly, turning where you think you have to turn, banging into dead ends, one thing after another...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ed emerges into the empty prison yard ringed by high stone walls. A hard spotlight shines down from above. Ed squints into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The spotlight is from a hovering flying saucer. We see its revolving underside and, as it irregularly cants, a bit of its top bubble. After spinning briefly, it tips and flies away, carrying the tremolo hum with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed turns and re-enters the prison.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...But get some distance on it, and all those twists and turns, why, they're the shape of your life. It's hard to explain...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...But seeing it whole gives you some peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue
